current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Overall, industry revenue is projected to grow at a CAGR of 0.9% to $17.4 billion through 2029.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Environmental concerns about single-use plastic products are emerging as a potential threat to the industry. While plastic is recyclable, many consumers will purchase single, large-volume containers instead of packs of smaller single-serve bottles.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry manufacture a range of bottles from various plastic compounds based on their end use. These bottles are then sold to beverage, food, and chemical manufacturers to use as packaging for soft drinks, milk, condiments, and household and automotive chemicals. This industry does not manufacture reusable plastic bottles or other plastic containers.

opportunities: Price of plastic materials and resin

key_trends: Imports remain a key threat to the industry. Buyers looking to cut costs have turned to less expensive foreign products or have chosen to invest in vertically integrated manufacturers.

Plastic bottle manufacturers have adapted to consumer preferences. Manufacturers are creating new bottles that adhere to stricter environmental standards to compete with reusable alternatives like glass or metal.
Companies must comply with EPA standards. Eliminating harmful oils and materials from production while reducing waste and using recyclable plastic will be crucial moving forward.
The Plastic Bottle Manufacturing industry receives support from tariffs. As a result, producers can focus on competing with other domestic manufacturers rather than those operating abroad.
Food and beverage manufacturers are the largest buyers of plastic bottles. Many consumers have opted for reusable containers, limiting this segment's growth.
New hot-fill technology has enabled manufacturers to unseat traditional hot food and beverage containers. Plastic bottle manufacturers have been able to displace glass bottles.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Beverage bottlers are the largest market segment supplied by this industry. Downstream products include bottles for soft drinks, juice, tea, beer, and dairy products, like milk and cream. Among beverage producers, soft drink manufacturers constitute the majority of plastic bottle purchases. Soft drink consumption has declined as the number of health-conscious consumers increases.

The introduction of hot-fill technology has enabled food manufacturers to replace glass bottles with plastic bottles for sauces and condiments. Food products, like seasoning and parmesan cheese, are also packaged in cylindrical bottles with wide-mouth snapping tops. Demand for bottled food products and beverages sold in businesses, cafeterias or hotels declined significantly during the pandemic as these places closed or limited foot traffic. Even so, many restaurants adapted take-out models, increasing plastic bottle usage.

This industry manufactures bottles for automotive and industrial products, including motor oil, coolants, and lubricants. During the pandemic, car usage declined as fewer people were commuting to work and traveling, minimizing the depreciation of cars, contributing to declining demand for automotive products and decreasing demand for plastic bottles for automotive and industrial products. As travel and commuting activity returns, this segment will expand. The high price of new and used cars will also increase demand for car maintenance products.

This segment includes household cleaning chemicals, detergents, and personal care products. Household items are often nondiscretionary, so demand from this market segment has remained stable. This market soared during the pandemic, following heightened demand for cleaning and sanitization products. While the vaccine rollout has stifled more significant increases, the emergence of new COVID-19 variants has kept demand elevated.

products_and_services.product_description: Beverage bottles, which include soft drink, water, juice, and dairy product bottles, account for the largest share of revenue. The falling popularity of soft drinks and the general decline in plastic packaging as companies switch to more environmentally friendly substitutes has pressured this segment. Instead, water and juice bottlers will take up a more significant share of demand. Demand for plastic coffee cups has also skyrocketed.
Food bottles made of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) used for sauces, salad dressings, and other condiments make up the second-largest share.

Household cleaning product manufacturers use plastic bottles to package cleaning products, including dish soap, laundry detergent, and household cleaners. These manufacturers also use plastic bottles for personal care products like soap, shampoo, conditioner, and lotion. Household cleaning product manufacturers often make larger bottles for laundry detergent from HDPE, a sturdier plastic that can support putting a built-in handle into the bottle for easy use. During the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, this segment ballooned; consumers purchased massive amounts of cleaning supplies to sanitize their homes and workplaces.

Automotive product containers, typically made of High-Density Poly Ethylene (HDPE), are used for products like oil and antifreeze. With remote work policies, fewer people commute to work and drive, reducing the need for bottled automotive and industrial products. Rising new and used car prices, though, have encouraged many car owners to invest in automotive liquids for maintenance. This segment has benefited from the introduction of hot-fill technology, which can produce plastics that withstand temperatures as high as 180 degrees Fahrenheit. This innovation has enabled plastic bottles to replace glass bottles.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: A rise in consumers' per capita disposable income permits greater spending on food, beverages, cleaning products and auto parts. As demand for these products increases, so will demand for plastic bottles.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Price of Plastic Materials and Resin
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Manufacturers use plastic resin to make the industry's products. Manufacturers can typically pass on adverse fluctuations in resin prices to downstream customers. The price of plastic materials and resin will likely increase in 2023, representing a potential opportunity for the industry.

Manufacturers use petrochemicals, derived from crude oil, to create plastics. The price of crude oil directly affects performance as manufacturers attempt to pass on price changes to customers, despite aggressive hedging to mitigate the impact of price swings. The price of crude oil will likely decline in 2023.

The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the performance of the US dollar relative to the currencies of the United States' major trading partners. As the TWI increases, domestic goods are more expensive in foreign markets, while imported goods grow more affordable to US consumers. The TWI will likely increase in 2023, posing a potential threat to the industry.

A rise in per capita soft drink consumption is positive for plastic bottle manufacturers since many beverage manufacturers package soft drinks in plastic bottles. Per capita soft drink consumption will likely decrease in 2023.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Low-cost Foreign Manufacturers Encroach on Domestic Producers
international_trade_points.trade_description: Since 2003, the industry has been a net importer, with the United States receiving a rapidly growing portion of imports from China. The abundance of inexpensive labor, government incentives and lower transportation costs have enabled China to produce plastic products at a lower price than the United States. Strict tariffs will limit Chinese imports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Stronger US Dollar in Recent Years has Impacted Trade Flows
international_trade_points.trade_description: Over the past few years, the US dollar has appreciated significantly, making imports relatively less expensive than domestic products. The trade-weighted index will level out, bringing the costs of foreign and domestic plastic bottles closer together.

international_trade_points.trade_title: UNITED STATES-MEXICO-CANADA AGREEMENT (USMCA) FACILITATES DEMAND FOR DOMESTIC GOODS
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada and Mexico are the industry's largest export markets, accounting for more than 70.0% of industry exports. The two countries benefit from their geographic proximity to the United States and the United States Mexico Canada Agreement (USMCA), which replaced the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) in 2020.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE US DOLLAR'S STRENGTH HAS MADE EXPORTS MORE EXPENSIVE
international_trade_points.trade_description: Domestic products have grown more costly through 2023 as the US dollar appreciates. With higher labor costs than foreign competitors, US producers can't offer the same prices as foreign producers. Over the next few years, though, the US dollar will decline in value. Domestic plastic bottle manufacturers will have the opportunity to lower prices and compete more directly with foreign manufacturers.

business_locations.location_description: The majority of establishments move to the highly populated Southeast region. Manufacturers use the crowded population to find less expensive work than in other areas. The region also facilitates trade from Mexico through ports in the Gulf and has an extensive infrastructure to other regions like the Mid-Atlantic.

California is the most populous state in the United States. It has direct access to Mexico, the second-largest importer of plastic bottles, making the state a strategic place for establishments. California also has a high level of manufacturing activity, making the state attractive for companies looking to cut down on transportation to critical markets.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Facilities within this industry are subject to extensive environmental legislation concerning waste management, air emissions, toxic use reduction and environmental cleanup, among others and are required to comply with other environmental laws and regulations.

Several states have enacted recycling legislation that requires that a specified minimum percentage of recycled plastic be included in certain new plastic containers. This legislative trend is expected to continue over the next decade.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Even as the industry automates, most steps of the plastic bottle manufacturing process require human involvement. Companies also need skilled workers for research and development and to operate new machinery.

basis_points.basis_title: Little variation in products within plastic bottle manufacturing
basis_points.basis_description: Manufacturers vie for business by offering lower prices, better performance attributes and stronger service.

basis_points.basis_title: Foreign manufacturers can outcompete domestic producers on price
basis_points.basis_description: Foreign manufacturers can outcompete domestic producers on price, resulting in greater import penetration. Tariffs and a declining TWI will help domestic producers regain their footing.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Major manufacturers take advantage of existing relationships
concentration_points.concentration_description: Relationships through long-term contracts with key customers have enabled the industry to be dominated by a few key manufacturers instead of being fragmented like other plastic manufacturing industries.

Large manufacturers benefit from economies of scale by lowering their per-unit costs and affording them greater profit. Small companies have struggled to maintain profitability as rising wage costs and input price volatility cut into profit, leading to greater consolidation activity.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rising Wage and Input Costs Limit Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: While many manufacturers negotiate long-term contracts with plastic suppliers, high volatility in oil and plastic prices has subdued profit. Manufacturers have been unable to pass on extreme input price changes to downstream markets. Wage costs have also encroached on profit, especially as companies invest in highly skilled employees for research and development groups.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Spurred by Growing R&D Investment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Plastic bottle manufacturers are investing more in their research and development (R&D) teams to produce more environmentally friendly products. Increased automation, though, has reduced the need for low-skill labor, keeping wage expenses relatively low. Even so, manufacturers must hire new, skilled labor to work complex machinery.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Remain High as Input Prices Grow Volatile
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The graph shows the percentage of revenue spent on purchases from 2005 to 2024 (projected). The purchases percentage fluctuates between around 40% to 60% over the years. In 2024, it is projected to be 51.2%, indicating relatively high purchase costs. The volatility in purchase costs is likely driven by fluctuations in input prices, particularly for raw materials like HDPE and PET resins used in plastic bottle manufacturing.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Even as the industry automates, most steps of the plastic bottle manufacturing process require human involvement. Companies also need skilled workers for research and development and to operate new machinery.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low threat of new disruptive technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Plastic Bottle Manufacturers Face Decline as Consumer Preferences Shift
volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers have increasingly opted to use renewable materials for beverages and foods. While these products are initially more expensive, consumers save money, especially as rising interest rates cloud the country's economic outlook. This trend is especially prevalent with water bottles.

Along with downstream demand, the price of inputs can also cause revenue to fluctuate heavily. The primary input in plastic bottles is plastic resin, a petroleum product. The COVID-19 pandemic and Russian invasion of Ukraine have caused oil prices to skyrocket, limiting the output of plastic resin manufacturers. Plastic bottle manufacturers have dealt with rising input prices, cutting into profit.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Consumer Preferences Cause a Shift in the Beverage Bottle Landscape
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The falling popularity of soft drinks and the general decline in plastic packaging as companies switch to more environmentally friendly substitutes has pressured this segment. Instead, water and juice bottlers will take up a more significant share of demand. Demand for plastic coffee cups has also skyrocketed.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Innovation Drives the Food Bottle Segment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment has benefited from the introduction of hot-fill technology, which can produce plastics that withstand temperatures as high as 180 degrees Fahrenheit. This innovation has enabled plastic bottles to replace glass bottles. Flexible plastic bottles that enable condiments to be squeezed directly from the container add another benefit over glass bottles.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Boosted the Chemical Cleaning Bottles Segment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: During the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, this segment ballooned; consumers purchased massive amounts of cleaning supplies to sanitize their homes and workplaces.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry have been under pressure from increasing import competition. Overseas manufacturers, particularly in China, have access to less expensive labor and input prices.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry depend on consumer behavior and oil price trends. Revenue is supported by consumer staple products sold by the industry.

FAQs.question: Has your company located near key downstream customers to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: It is common practice for companies in this industry to set up near key customers. Sometimes they even locate in the same manufacturing complex as their key customer.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Being in the business of plastics, the industry is very exposed to the volatile input of oil.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry have increasingly invested in automation in recent years.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry regularly file patents for new designs or manufacturing processes.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The push for biodegradable packaging from local, state and federal governments has made companies in this industry search for alternatives to petroleum-based plastic for their raw materials.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry are represented by the Society of the Plastics Industry (SPI) and the Manufacturers Association for Plastics Processors.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Comparison between manufacturers in the industry and their competitors depends on the products they manufacture, the size of their operations and the clients they serve. Input prices for raw materials like nonferrous metal influence the profit of aluminum can manufacturers, the industry's main competitor in the food and beverage market.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Profit in this industry has an inverse relationship with oil prices, meaning that a fall in oil prices often translates to higher profit.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? Have you had any issues securing or keeping contracts?
FAQs.answer: A reliable supply of critical inputs, like plastic resin, at a competitive cost increases a manufacturer's profitability.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? What is your budget for expanding operations?
FAQs.answer: The development of large-scale production facilities enables manufacturers to increase profitability through lower production costs per unit.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: Plastic bottle manufacturers must maintain consistent quality in their products. Any deviation from consistency may cause an operator to lose business.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the price of crude oil? When the price increases, are you able to pass on these high costs?
FAQs.answer: Plastics are derived from petrochemicals, which are derived from crude oil. The price of crude oil directly affects industry performance.

FAQs.question: How have demand fluctuations from soda production impacted your business in the past? What customers do you have outside of this declining industry?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers mostly sell plastic bottles to beverage bottlers. Beverage product marketing and the economic climate collectively influence demand for bottles.

FAQs.question: Do you track trends in consumers' disposable income? Are you able to charge higher prices when disposable income increases?
FAQs.answer: A rise in consumers' per capita disposable income permits greater spending on food, beverages, cleaning products and auto parts. As demand for these products increases, so will demand plastic bottles.
